profileText: A Representative from New York; born in New Bedford, Mass., March 3, 1803; pursued an academic course; entered a countingroom in New York City in 1818; subsequently engaged in mercantile pursuits; elected as a Whig to the Twenty-sixth Congress (March 4, 1839-March 3, 1841); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1840 to the Twenty-seventh Congress; presidential elector on the Republican ticket in 1856; president of the chamber of commerce and of the Merchants Clerks' Savings Bank; commissioner of charities and corrections; Central Park commissioner; one of the Union defense committee; collector of the port of New York from March 1869 to July 1870; appointed naval officer of customs and served from July 1870 to April 1871; died in New York City November 24, 1877; interment in Sleepy Hollow Burying Ground, Tarrytown, N.Y.

note.content: One of four elected to represent the third district.

researchRecord.name: In the Edwin Denison Morgan Papers, 1830-1872, 50 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Subjects covered in the correspondence include Moses H. Grinnell. An unpublished finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Park Benjamin Papers, 1645-1925, 6.5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Subjects covered in the papers include Moses Hicks Grinnell. A contents list is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the John Lothrop Motley Papers, 1842-1873, 26 items.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include Moses Hicks Grinnell.

researchRecord.name: 1863, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Moses Hicks Grinnell to Edward Bates, Attorney General, written in May 1863. In the letter, Moses Grinnell recommends Thomas J. Boynton as judge of the southern district court of Florida. The letter is also signed by nineteen other underwriters and merchants.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In the Grinnell Family Papers, 1799-1892, 141 items.
researchRecord.description: Includes the business records of the company Fish, Grinnell & Company. Moses Hicks Grinnell and his brothers, Joseph Grinnell and Henry Grinnell, were in charge of the company. The company reorganized again in 1832 and was renamed Grinnell, Minturn & Company. The firm initially handled oil and candle business of New Bedford merchants, later branched out as ship owners, operators of packet lines to Great Britain, and merchants trading in Latin America, Cuba, China, and England. Also include family materials of Moses Grinnell. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the John Stevenson Maxwell Papers, 1830-1863, approximately 150 items.
researchRecord.description: Includes correspondence from Moses H. Grinnell to Secretary of State John M. jClayton recommending John Stevenson Maxwell's appointment as resident minister at Constantinople.

researchRecord.name: 1861, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Moses Hicks Grinnell to [Thurlow] Weed written approximately on March 6, 1861.

researchRecord.name: In the James Hopkinson Papers, 1836-1846, 17 items.
researchRecord.description: Subjects covered in the correspondence include Moses Hicks Grinnell.

recordLocation.name: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library
